text: I think <@UAJKEBGP8> brings up a great point: there's a distinction to be made here between _negative_ feedback, and _critical_ feedback. Purely negative feedback ("this is crap", "why would you waste your time on that?") usually comes from people who wish you ill, but the best critical feedback comes from those who want you to succeed, and who are well-intended in their criticisms (that's not to say that this sort of feedback can't be incisive -- it often is, but i'll deal with that later). In my view, the only feedback that you should consider acting on is that which comes from the sorts of people who mean well. But just like hearing your mother shouting "clean your room!", it is often difficult and uncomfortable to deal with such advice, and it often comes across as curt or abrasive. The best way I've found is to look at feedback, not as a criticism of my "self", but rather as being critical of some work I've produced or some action I've taken. That may sound cliché, but if someone's well-intentioned criticism of your work bothers you deeply, you need to examine your personal reasons for why that is the case. Like Marcus Aurelius said: _“we all love ourselves more than other people, but care more about their opinion than our own”_ :deciduous_tree:

text:
> if someone's well-intentioned criticism of your work bothers you deeply, you need to examine your personal reasons for why that is the case.
If you've worked hard on something, and you're invested in it, the expectation is that criticism would bother you, is it not? Well-intentioned most of all, I'd imagine, because then it's more likely to be true? That's sort of what I'm looking for, what's the mental model you'd use to remove emotion from the equation?

Examples would take too much context unfortunately, but generally, I'm talking about good feedback. And I guess I would say I usually respond fine. Re Aurelius, I'm actually pretty internally motivated. But something still always bothers me, these interactions *never feel graceful*. I always feel like I gave something up when I respond if that makes any sense. So I was wondering how others handle it and think about it.

text:
Advice from people who are sincere toward you is not more or less liable to be objectively true, it’s just likely to be more carefully considered and deliberate than feedback that comes from someone whose intentions are less-than-sincere.

When it comes to responding to feedback with grace, that’s definitely an art, and one that I need to practice on a daily basis. In addition to putting myself in the feedback-giver’s shoes, it’s helpful to do things to moderate my reactions in the moment: “pressing the pause button”, so to speak, is super underrated. Whenever possible, I try to wait a length of time that’s proportional to the intensity of my initial reaction to a criticism I get before I respond to it. In cases where I’m very firmly invested in the work that I’ve done, this might be days, but in cases like this (where I’ve received good feedback, and the downside to sharing my reaction is fairly limited), a couple minutes is often enough. I find this most challenging to do in face-to-face settings, which is the reason I tend to solicit feedback primarily in written form (which has mercifully become more acceptable as a result of _certain world events_). If I don’t think I can respond to a given piece of feedback in a manner that I would appreciate coming from someone else, that’s my cue to dig deeper into why I had that reaction.

text:
<@UG0EL18H3>'s advice about spending time with your feelings and trying to understand them before reacting reflexively is great in... (checks notes)... every other aspect of your life. It's the sort of thing that primary education ought to teach, but doesn't.

In terms of "the expectation is that criticism would bother you", it is normative to feel prickled by criticism, but the more productive framing is gratitude for an opportunity to improve this thing about which you care so much. There's nothing easy about moving from defensive to open hearted, but it's one of the most worthwhile things you can do.
